risinfo.chaptertitle: 21. Interviewing Individuals at Risk for Suicide

sect2.title: “Janice”
sect2.para: As a 20-year-old gay Latina Latina college student, Janice screened positive for suicidal thoughts on an ASQ that was administered by an emergency department (ED) nurse. She was brought to the ED by her roommate who witnessed Janice impulsively overdose on her SSRI antidepressant and medications after a fierce fight and break up with her girlfriend of 3 years. Janice remained extremely anxious, dysregulated, and inconsolable in the ED and was subsequently admitted to an inpatient psychiatric unit. The day after her admission, Janice met with a psychology intern on the unit who administered a C-SSRS, a Beck Depression Inventory, and a Beck Anxiety Inventory. In addition, the intern also conducted a 45-minute assessment interview.

The intern had been well trained in suicide assessment and was both empathic and validating. In the course of their interview, Janice acknowledged that she did not really want to die, stating: “I just didn’t know what else to do—I can’t imagine living without her.” Janice occasionally experienced passing suicidal thoughts suicidal thoughts in high school after a classmate took his life, but this overdose was her first suicide attempt. Janice tearfully disclosed a fairly extensive history of self-harm cutting behavior behavior that was always triggered by acutely anxious states mostly related to family of origin conflicts. Her family relationships were complicated by years of sexual abuse by her maternal grandfather and her sexual orientation which was unacceptable to her devotedly Catholic family. Janice noted that all her relationships tended to be volatile and intense.

After several days on the inpatient unit, Janet was referred to a community treatment center and put on a 3-month waiting list for Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT) Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT) . In the meantime, she would receive supportive counseling and family therapy was strongly recommended.

sect3.title: Comment on the Case of Janice
sect3.para: As a 20-something, marginalized, gay woman, over-dosing on medication following a relationship conflict, Janice represents a modal suicide attempter within the United States. Her history of sexual trauma, anxiety, depression, and self-harm cutting behavior along with volatile relationships all contribute to the complexity of her case. Given this history and set of symptoms, Janice would be an excellent candidate for intensive DBT, but waitlists for receiving this excellent evidence-based treatment are not atypical.

Of note, the distinction between her self-harm behaviors and suicide is important to make (and patients need psycho-education on this distinction). Janice did not aspire to terminate her biological existence; she just did not otherwise know how to cope with her intense dysregulation in the wake of her breakup. Her overdose on SSRIs is not objectively lethal but is nevertheless concerning. The absence of any other previous attempts is important. If Janice is able to receive DBT to learn emotion regulation skills and engage in family therapy (and perhaps some trauma-informed therapy), her prognosis could be promising but such care can be elusive, time-consuming, and expensive.

sect2.title: “Frank”
sect2.para: As a divorced, alcoholic, middle-aged (53), white male, electrical engineer, Frank has struggled with a history of depression and several failed attempts to become sober. Estranged from his three sons and at risk of losing his job at a power company, Frank recently bought a handgun and had written several suicide notes to his ex-wife and sons to say goodbye. At work, and to his surprise, Frank broke down in tears and shared with a work colleague that he was depressed and “ready to give up.” The astute astute colleague walked Frank down to the personnel office and an evaluation with an Employee Assistance Program (EAP) Employee Assistance Program (EAP) psychologist was immediately made.

The savvy EAP clinician administered a C-SSRS and noted Frank’s serious suicidal risk. In a calm, even manner, he talked to Frank about possible treatment options that would be covered under the company’s health plan. Frank admitted to the EAP clinician that he was reluctant to reveal his suicidal thinking because he feared being hospitalized against his will. While the clinician acknowledged that hospitalization is sometimes necessary, there are excellent suicide-focused treatments that can be conducted on an outpatient basis. Toward the end of their 2-h interview, the EAP EAP clinician referred Frank to an in-network clinical social worker who could provide an intervention called the “Collaborative Assessment and Management of Suicidality” (CAMS) (CAMS) and an appointment with her was made for later in the week. While skeptical, Frank nevertheless felt guardedly guardedly encouraged and was grateful for the compassionate EAP response.

sect3.title: Comment on the Case of Frank
sect3.para: Within the first session of CAMS CAMS Frank received an in-depth assessment of his suicide risk using a tool called the “Suicide Status Form” that was completed collaboratively by Frank and his clinician (sitting side-by-side). The SSF in-depth assessment led to the development of the CAMS Stabilization Plan and a suicide-focused treatment plan that centered on identifying Franks “drivers” of suicide. In Frank’s case, a key initial intervention involved removing access to the new handgun (which was taken by his co-worker for safe keeping). Frank’s CAMS treatment intensively focused on alleviating his suicidal drivers (i. e., his two problem drivers focused on re-engaging with his sons and getting sober). While Frank is a worrisome clinical presentation, he did not need to be hospitalized because lethal means were quickly secured, a solid Stabilization Plan was established, and he received an evidence-based suicide-focused treatment.

The handling of Frank’s case is an excellent example of superb clinical risk management response that is ethical and optimal as least-restrictive, evidence-based, and suicide-focused care was provided, which was in Frank’s best interest and was simply the right thing to do (Jobes & Barnett, 2024 ). Two years after six sessions of CAMS CAMS , Frank was sober and spending time with his sons after engaging in successful family therapy. With his suicide clinically averted, and a solid program of sobriety, Frank was dating a woman in recovery and he reported feeling like he had been “reborn” into a life worth living.
